facts.text: Learned Judicial Magistrate, 1st Class, Sunam convicted the appellant under section 9 of the Opium Act for being in possession of over 1 kg. of opium without a licence and sentenced him to suffer rigorous imprisonment for 8 months and to pay a fine of Rs. 500/-
Order of conviction and sentence was confirmed in appeal by the learned Sessions Judge, Sangrur
Conviction confirmed in revision by the High Court of Punjab and Haryana in Criminal Revision No. 66 of 1969 dated 12th February, 1970
Appellant was arrested on June 9, 1968 under section 54 of the Code of Criminal Procedure
While in police lock-up, appellant allegedly made a statement that he had kept a tin containing opium in his house
Gurdev Singh, SHO Lehra Police Station, asked constable to secure two Panchas (Kehar Singh and Krishan Chand)
Police party went to appellant's house; appellant produced a tin of opium weighing 1 kg. and 300 gms. and handed it over to Gurdev Singh
Appellant examined seven witnesses in support of defence that he was arrested on June 8, 1968 at Nagla where he runs a liquor shop

Before leaving Nagla, appellant and companion Jagdish Rai presented application before Sarpanch of village panchayat stating apprehension of false charge due to enmity; produced application and receipt acknowledging fee paid
Appellant denied making statement about opium or producing the opium tin
Kehar Singh was charged by police in case under section 429 IPC and cited as prosecution witness in case against Gajjan Singh
Krishan Chand figured as accused in prosecution under section 382 IPC by Sham Lal and concerned with commencement of security proceedings against Hans Raj
Krishan Chand's uncle Mohan Lal was rival candidate against appellant in municipal elections of Lehra, and appellant won
Kehar Singh stated whole police party entered room from which opium was discovered
Krishan Chand initially supported but later conceded: Did not enter room; sat on chabutra outside with Kehar Singh while SHO sat on cot
Gurdev Singh had seen the two panchas before the case and was not fully known to them
Ex. P.A., alleged statement by appellant at police station, bears appellant's signature and contains unqualified admission of concealing tin of opium
No case registered against appellant before house search
Appellant not asked in examination under section 342 CrPC for explanation regarding statement Ex. P.A.

legal_issues.text: Whether the prosecution story of recovery of opium on basis of appellant's disclosure statement, supported by panch witnesses, is credible and establishes possession of opium without licence under section 9 Opium Act
Whether defence evidence deserves consideration or can be summarily rejected
Reliability of panch witnesses Kehar Singh and Krishan Chand given their backgrounds and contradictions in testimony

petitioner_arguments.text: Arrested on June 8, 1968 at Nagla liquor shop; presented application to Sarpanch apprehending false charge due to enmity; denied making disclosure statement or producing opium tin
Examined seven witnesses in support of defence

respondent_arguments.text: Relied heavily on Ex. P.A., the disclosure statement bearing appellant's signature, containing unqualified admission of concealing opium tin, sufficient to sustain conviction

court_reasoning.text: Prosecution story inherently impossible of belief; three courts concurrently held against appellant but failed to appreciate mutually destructive statements of prosecution witnesses and summarily rejected defence evidence
court_reasoning.key_observation: Story fiction-like; panchas not respectable (Kehar Singh charged u/s 429 IPC, Krishan Chand accused u/s 382 IPC, family rivalry); contradictions on whether they witnessed recovery

court_reasoning.text: Panchas not true witnesses to seizure; pretence of search; SHO knew them previously; no reliance on signed statement due to infirmities in recording witnesses and no explanation sought u/s 342 CrPC
court_reasoning.key_observation: Defence witnesses not to be assumed always untrustworthy; prosecution evidence open to criticism

court_reasoning.text: High Court wrongly believed Kehar Singh due to his charge showing police not favourable; ignored rivalry and contradictions; brushed aside defence as fabricated without scrutiny
court_reasoning.key_observation: No influence of appellant evident; documents fabricable by anyone

holdings.text: Prosecution evidence unreliable due to inherent improbabilities, unreliable panchas, contradictions; no reliance on signed statement without proper examination u/s 342 CrPC
Defence evidence requires careful scrutiny, not summary rejection

statutes_cited.relevance: Conviction for possession of over 1 kg opium without licence

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave allowed; order of conviction and sentence set aside due to unreliable prosecution evidence and failure to appreciate defence
outcome.relief_granted: Acquittal by setting aside conviction and sentence

key_quotes.text: The story of the prosecution is so inherently impossible of belief that we are unable to persuade ourselves to stay our hands and let the conviction and sentence stand.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reason for overturning concurrent findings of lower courts

key_quotes.text: Defence witnesses are often untrustworthy but it is wrong for that reason to assume that they always lie and that the prosecution witnesses are always trustworthy.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Critique of lower courts' approach to evidence appreciation

key_quotes.text: It is obvious from these admissions that Kehar Singh and Krishan Chand were not in any sense witnesses to the seizure of the opium.
key_quotes.speaker: court
